Clutching forks and knives to eat their bacon

This is probably a reference to a latin “Homo homini lupus est”, which is similar to the English expression, “dog eat dog”, meaning humans are enemies to each other and constantly in conflict with one another, with their only interest being self-preservation and satisfaction.

The “bigger piggies” don’t care that they are eating their own kind, as they’re too rich and high and mighty for it to affect them. This mirrors the real-life idea that those in the upper class can do such awful things while being completely oblivious to its potential effect on people.

This sort of thing happens in Animal Farm, where Napoleon and the other “superior” pigs end up executing and sending to slaughter the other animals on the farm, despite agreeing at the beginning that they were one family who would all be respected equally.
Always have clean shirts to play around in

This is both literal and metaphorical.  A clean ironed dress shirt is a symbol of higher paying work, but it’s also contrasting the filth of the lowly pigs with the cleanliness of the wealthy pigs.

Like in Orwell’s Animal Farm, the pigs were emulating human behaviors and wearing clothes to distinguish themselves from the other pigs.  This line is basically a way of saying that the pigs can cause all the dirt they want and just put on a new clean shirt whenever they want to.
Everywhere there’s lots of piggies living piggy lives
It is a little ironic that we teach kids to save – in a Piggy Bank, and then use “Piggies” in a derogatory fashion to describe corrupt, spoiled, non caring capitalists.
Have you seen the bigger piggies in their starched white shirts?
Harrison’s venom now switches to the capitalist leaders themselves, the bankers and accountants that were beginning to develop vast wealth.
What they need’s a damn good whacking!

This line was contributed by Harrison’s mother, Louise.

From Harrison’s 1980 autobiography I Me Mine:

I was stuck for one line in the middle until my mother came up with the lyric “What they need is a damn good whacking!” (a damned good throttling) which is a nice simple way of saying they need a good hiding. It needed to rhyme with “backing”, “lacking” and had absolutely nothing to do with American policemen or Californian shagnasties!
